content.content: Stacks is a programmability layer with a novel execution environment, Clarity.

content.title: No Enforcement of State Validation
content.content: The validity of Stacks state transitions is not enforced by Bitcoin. However, Stacks has a permissionless and sufficiently decentralized validator set which enforces transaction validity, which is why this risk is Medium and not High.

content.title: State Roots Only
content.content: Stacks posts state roots to Bitcoin, but not full transaction calldata. Because of this, Stacks' state cannot be reconstructed using only data from Bitcoin.

content.title: Decentralized Block Production
content.content: Stacks has a sufficiently decentralized block production mechanism, but it does not support exits that circumvent its validator set. This is why the risk is Medium and not Low.

content.title: No Enshrined BTC Bridge
content.content: Stacks has no consensus-enshrined BTC bridge. It does have two custodial multisig bridges, which are not trustless.

content.title: No Enshrined BTC Bridge
content.content: Stacks has no consensus-enshrined BTC bridge. It does have two custodial multisig bridges, which are not trustless.

content.title: The rollup relies on Bitcoin for data availability and consensus
content.content: Moneta's state can be reconstructed based on the data that is stored on the Bitcoin blockchain.

content.title: Bitcoin Hashpower is used in securing Moneta
content.content: Bitcoin hashpower used to mine blocks containing transactions that include Citrea's state transitions.

content.title: Moneta does not have an alternative token
content.content: Moneta uses a BTC voucher to operate the rollup.

content.title: Validity proofs ensure state correctness
content.content: Each state transition must contain a validity proof that proves that execution was done correctly to a series of user transactions. If these a proof includes an invalid state transition, then a verifier in the BitVM set up can submit a fraud proof to challenge the state transition.

content.title: Zero knowledge STARK cryptography is used
content.content: State transitions are proven through cryptographic proofs known as zkSTARKs. If an implementation of the cryptography was done incorrectly, user funds can be at risk. STARKs do not require a trusted set up.

content.title: The system has a centralized operator
content.content: Block production is managed by one entity. Users trust this entity to act in the best interests of the system.

content.title: Withdrawals rely on 1-N trust assumptions
content.content: In the event that the systems are operators are acting honestly, users trust that 1 party in the BitVM bridge set up is acting honestly and will permit their withdrawals from the L2.

content.title: The node software is open-source and available
content.content: The node software is open-source, and its source code can be found here. Users can run a node with their own hardware, or through a cloud service provider.
